focus_skills: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread

questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 8 to both sides: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. Divide both sides by 5: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable step-by-step by performing inverse operations on both sides of the equation.

questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Distribute: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi></math>. Combine like terms: <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and <math><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>. So the expression simplifies to <math><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When simplifying expressions, carefully distribute each term and then combine like terms (terms with the same variable and exponent).

questions.question: A store increases the price of an item by 25%. After a month, the store decreases the new price by 20%. The final price is what percent of the original price?
questions.explanation: Let the original price be <math><mi>p</mi></math>. After a 25% increase: <math><mn>1.25</mn><mi>p</mi></math>. After a 20% decrease: <math><mn>0.80</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1.25</mn><mi>p</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>p</mi></math>. The final price equals the original price, which is 100% of it.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For successive percent changes, multiply by <math><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>r</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math> for increases and <math><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>r</mi><mn>100</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math> for decreases.

questions.question: A rectangular garden has a length of 12 feet and a width of 8 feet. A path of uniform width is built around the garden, increasing the total area to 165 square feet. What is the width of the path, in feet?
questions.explanation: Let the path width be <math><mi>w</mi></math>. The new dimensions are <math><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>)</mo></math> by <math><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Area: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>165</mn></math>. Expanding: <math><mn>96</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>40</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>w</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>165</mn></math> → <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>w</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>40</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>69</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Using the quadratic formula: <math><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>±</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>1600</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1104</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>52</mn></mrow><mn>8</mn></mfrac></math>. The positive solution is <math><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For problems involving borders, remember to add the border width twice to both length and width.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mi>x</mi></msup></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>63</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For exponential functions, remember the order of operations: evaluate the exponent first, then multiply.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> and <math><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: From the second equation: <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>19</mn></math>. Substitute into the first: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>19</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>57</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mn>14</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>74</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math>. Then <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>19</mn><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>148</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>133</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math>. So <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>52</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>≈</mo><mn>7.43</mn></math>. The closest integer option is 7.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For systems, substitution or elimination are reliable methods. Check your arithmetic carefully.

questions.question: The graph of <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is a parabola with vertex at <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. If the graph passes through the point <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, which of the following could define <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Vertex form: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math> with vertex <math><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Here <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, so <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Use point (5,0): <math><mn>0</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></math> → <math><mn>0</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. So <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For parabola vertex problems, start with vertex form and use a given point to solve for the leading coefficient.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='380' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='40' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>0</text><text x='100' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>1</text><text x='150' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>2</text><text x='200' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>3</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>4</text><text x='300' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>5</text><text x='350' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>6</text><text x='35' y='255' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>0</text><text x='35' y='205' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>5</text><text x='35' y='155' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>10</text><text x='35' y='105' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>15</text><text x='35' y='55' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>20</text><text x='200' y='295' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Hours Driven (x)</text><text x='15' y='150' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold' transform='rotate(-90 15,150)'>Fuel Remaining (y)</text><circle cx='100' cy='60' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='150' cy='85' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='200' cy='105' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='250' cy='140' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='300' cy='155' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='350' cy='190' r='4' fill='blue'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot measuring Fuel Remaining (y-axis) against Hours Driven (x-axis). The x-axis ranges from 0 to 6. The y-axis ranges from 0 to 20. The data points show a strong negative correlation, starting high on the y-axis and descending as x increases.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between the number of hours a vehicle has been driven and the amount of fuel remaining in its tank. A line of best fit for the data has the equation <math display='inline'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>22</mn></math>, where <math display='inline'><mi>x</mi></math> is the hours driven and <math display='inline'><mi>y</mi></math> is the fuel remaining in gallons. According to the model, what is the predicted amount of fuel remaining after driving for 3 hours?
questions.explanation:
To find the predicted fuel remaining, substitute the value x=3 into the line of best fit equation:

y=−2.5(3)+22

y=−7.5+22

y=14.5
Therefore, the model predicts 14.5 gallons of fuel remaining.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a linear model <math display='inline'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math> is provided, predictions are made by substituting the given variable (x or y) into the equation and solving for the unknown.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='130,250 250,250 250,90' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 250,130 A 40,40 0 0 1 230,125' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='4,4'/><text x='115' y='260' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-weight='bold'>A</text><text x='260' y='260' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-weight='bold'>B</text><text x='255' y='85' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-weight='bold'>C</text><text x='190' y='270' font-size='14'>12</text><text x='260' y='180' font-size='14'>?</text><text x='230' y='155' font-size='14'>x°</text><rect x='240' y='240' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right-angled triangle ABC. The right angle is at vertex B. Vertex A is to the left, and Vertex C is at the top. Side AB (horizontal) is labeled '12'. The angle at vertex C is labeled 'x°'. The side BC (vertical) is the unknown side.
questions.question: In the right triangle <math display='inline'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown, the angle at <math display='inline'><mi>C</mi></math> measures <math display='inline'><mi>x</mi></math> degrees, and side <math display='inline'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> has a length of 12. If <math display='inline'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>, what is the length of side <math display='inline'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
Identify the sides relative to angle x (at vertex C):
  • Opposite: Side AB (length 12)
  • Adjacent: Side BC (unknown length)

Recall the definition of tangent:
tan(x)=OppositeAdjacent
Substitute the known values into the equation:
34=12BC
Cross-multiply to solve for BC:
3(BC)=4(12)
3(BC)=48
BC=16
questions.score_improvement_tip: To solve trigonometry problems correctly, always label the sides (Hypotenuse, Opposite, Adjacent) relative to the specific angle in question before setting up your ratio (SOH CAH TOA).

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mi>x</mi></msup></math>. If <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Set <math><mn>8</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mi>k</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Divide by 8: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mi>k</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac></math>. Since <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math>, we have <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving exponential equations, try to express both sides with the same base.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>g</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi></math> is a constant. If <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>16</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: First, find <math><mi>a</mi></math> using <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>16</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For polynomial functions given in factored form, use a given point to solve for the leading coefficient, then evaluate at another point.

questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo><</mo><mn>7</mn></math> and <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>≥</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, which of the following represents all possible values of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve each inequality separately. First: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo><</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>12</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Second: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>≥</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Combine: <math><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When combining inequalities, pay close attention to whether the endpoints are included (≤ or ≥) or excluded (< or >).

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, where <math><mi>k</mi></math> is a constant. If <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math> is a factor of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: If <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math> is a factor, then <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Substitute: <math><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mn>27</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mo>−</mo><mn>21</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>21</mn></math> → <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If (x - r) is a factor of a polynomial P(x), then P(r) = 0 (Remainder Theorem).

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: Working alone, Pump A can fill a tank in 4 hours. Working alone, Pump B can fill the same tank in 6 hours. If both pumps work together for 1 hour, and then Pump B stops, how many additional hours will Pump A need to finish filling the tank?
questions.explanation: Pump A rate: <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> tank/hour. Pump B rate: <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math> tank/hour. Together for 1 hour: <math><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac></math> tank filled. Remaining: <math><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac></math> tank. Pump A alone: time = <math><mfrac><mrow><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac></mrow><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>28</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> hours.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For combined work problems, add rates to find the together rate. Remember: work = rate × time.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='0' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><path d='M 200 150 L 280 150 A 80 80 0 0 0 240 80.7 Z' fill='#f0f0f0' stroke='none'/><path d='M 280 150 A 80 80 0 0 0 240 80.7 L 280 150' fill='#d3d3d3' stroke='none'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='80' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='280' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='240' y2='80.7' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='240' y1='80.7' x2='280' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><path d='M 230 150 A 30 30 0 0 0 220 133' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='1'/><text x='185' y='155' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>O</text><text x='290' y='155' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='235' y='70' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='235' y='140' font-size='12'>60°</text><text x='230' y='165' font-size='12' fill='gray'>r=8</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O and radius 8. Radii OA and OB form a 60-degree central angle. A chord connects points A and B. The region bounded by the chord AB and the minor arc AB (the circular segment) is shaded.
questions.question: In the circle with center O, radius 8, and <math><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the area of the shaded segment bounded by chord <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> and minor arc <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
To find the area of the segment, subtract the area of triangle AOB from the area of the sector AOB.

1. Area of Sector: Area=θ360πr2. With r=8 and θ=60°:
60360π(82)=16(64π)=32π3.

2. Area of Triangle: Since OA=OB=8 and the included angle is 60°, triangle AOB is equilateral. The area of an equilateral triangle is 34s2.
34(82)=34(64)=163.

3. Subtract: Area of Segment = 32π3-163.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The area of a circular segment is found by calculating the Area of the Sector and subtracting the Area of the Triangle formed by the radii and the chord.

questions.question: If <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is a solution to the system of equations <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the system. From the second equation: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Substitute into the first: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>7</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math> → <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. So <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Solve systems by substitution or elimination. Check your arithmetic to avoid errors.

questions.question: If <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> for all <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math> are constants, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Note denominator factors: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Multiply both sides by <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Expand: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Equate coefficients: For x: <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. For constants: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Solving: Add the two equations: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, then <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. So <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For partial fraction decomposition, clear denominators, expand, and equate coefficients of corresponding powers of x.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 180,140' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='180' y1='140' x2='180' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><rect x='180' y='190' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='90' y='210' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='310' y='210' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='175' y='130' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='175' y='215' font-size='12'>D</text><text x='185' y='170' font-size='12'>h</text><text x='135' y='215' font-size='12'>8</text><text x='235' y='215' font-size='12'>12</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC with base AB horizontal. The altitude from C drops to point D on the base. The base is split into two segments: left segment AD labeled 8 and right segment DB labeled 12. The altitude is labeled h.
questions.question: In triangle ABC, the altitude from C to AB intersects AB at point D such that <math><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> and <math><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. If the area of triangle ABC is <math><mn>60</mn></math>, what is the length of altitude CD?
questions.explanation: Area of triangle = <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mi>base</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>height</mi></math>. Here base <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. Let altitude <math><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>h</mi></math>. Then area = <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math> which implies <math><mn>10</mn><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>, so <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The area of a triangle is half the product of any base and its corresponding height.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The mean of five numbers is 12. If one of the numbers is removed, the mean of the remaining four numbers is 11. What is the value of the number that was removed?
questions.explanation: Let the five numbers sum to S. Mean = 12, so S = 5 × 12 = 60. After removing one number, call it x, the sum of the remaining four is 60 − x. Their mean is 11, so 60 − x = 4 × 11 = 44. Thus, x = 60 − 44 = 16.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall that mean = (sum of values) / (number of values). Use this to set up equations.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. What is the minimum value of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Complete the square: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Since <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mi></mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the minimum occurs when this square is 0, at x=3. Then <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a quadratic in standard form, the vertex (and thus min/max) can be found by completing the square or using x = -b/(2a).
